III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
Genesee County Juvenile Justice Center (GCJJC) is located in Flint Township,
Michigan. The facility is a secure two-story building. The building is comprised of the
personnel and administrative offices; intake unit; medical unit; kitchen, two dining rooms
and two gymnasiums. The residents’ records are kept in the administrative section of
the building in secure, locked files. An ample supply of desks, office furniture and other
office equipment exists to meet the staff’s needs. Emergency exits and equipment is
also visible in the building.
The residents are housed in the portion of building that consists of four resident wings
(North, South, East, West). Three wings are in operational status, while the fourth wing
2

(South) is not currently in use to house youths. The East and West Wings are for male
residents and the North Wing services both male and females. Each wing has a group/
TV/activity room, lockers and storage area for the youths, bathroom and shower area
and staff outer area. The East wing has occupancy for 26 youths, West wing 26 youths
and North wing 20 youths. All three resident wings have single and double occupancy
rooms, with the majority of the rooms being single rooms. The facility has a secure area
for medication storage on each wing. The classrooms, which contains desks,
computers, and an ample supply of equipment to meet the youth’s needs are between
the east and west wings on a separate corridor. There are also two large visitation
rooms, each equipped with monitors, cameras, and seating to accommodate
parent/child visitations. Both are capable of in person and virtual visits.
There is ample parking for staff and visitors; and the facility has a fenced in outside
recreational area.
B. Program Description
Genesee County Juvenile Justice Center (GCJJC) is a secure juvenile detention facility
operated under the 7th Judicial Circuit Court. GCJJC’s purpose centers on supporting
justice and public safety by providing short term programming for youths, court ordered
into juvenile detention, pending the court’s disposition of the youth’s case. The facility is
a 72-bed facility designed to provide short-term residential care to youths between the
ages of 10 to 17 years, who have been arrested for law violations. The youth is retained
at the facility pending adjudication of his/her offenses. The youth can continue at
GCJJC until a long-term treatment program, release to a parent/guardian, appropriate
identified continuum of care placement in the community, or escalation to a more
restrictive setting is court ordered/identified for the youth.
GCJJC is transformed from the Genesee Valley Regional Center (GVRC) juvenile
detention facility, which found its start in 1957 when it became apparent that Genesee
County needed to lodge youth in a more secure setting. With the increase in cost,
Genesee County sold the facility to the State of Michigan for operation by the
Department. In 2002, the State of Michigan turned the facility back over to Genesee
County as an independent county ran Child Caring Institution (CCI). The center’s
director was an appointed position of the Genesee County Board of Commissioners and
answered to the commissioners about operation and budgetary regulations. In the fall of
2019, the Genesee County Commissioners voted that the operation and budget would
be turned over to the Genesee County 7th Judicial Circuit Court for management.
GCJJC will provide youths placed in this facility with an initial health screening; medical
examination, educational services, and mental health and other professional services
that are contracted via various community resources. The Flushing School District
services GCJJC’s area of location, but the facility has contracted for educational
services from Mt. Morris School District. The school program is fully accredited and
taught by Special Education Certified teachers from the Mount Morris School District.
The teachers have experience working with delinquent youth.
3

GCJJC will use peer group support as a component of the behavior management
program. Programming will also include daily recreation, daily group counseling, and
individual counseling, as needed. The staff utilizes Core Correctional Practices (CCP)
and CHOICES, two cognitive-behavioral models developed by the University of
Cincinnati Corrections Institute (UCCI) that places heavy accent on skill building
activities to assist with a youth’s cognitive, social, emotional, and coping skill
development.
Single occupant sleeping rooms are approved as behavior management rooms. Handle
with care is the discipline/Behavioral Management Modality utilized, which has
emphasis on verbal escalation and role modeling.
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
There are no rule violations.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
The issuance of an original license for a court operated facility is recommended.
